text:
General Procedure for Conversion



The dual of the dual is the primal!




The objective coefficient vector of the primal becomes the right-hand-side vector of the dual constraints,
The right-hand-side vector of the primal constraints becomes the objective coefficient vector of the dual,
The transpose of the constraint matrix of the primal becomes the constraint matrix of the dual,
Every primal variable corresponds o a constraint in the dual, and its sign decides the sense of the dual constraint,
Every primal constraint corresponds to a variable in the dual, and its sense decides the sign of the dual variable.

max2x1+x2(dual var.)s.t.x1+83x2≤4,(y1)x1+x2≤2(y2)2x1≤3(y3)x1,x2≥0.\begin{align}
\operatorname{max} & 2x_1 + x_2 & (\text{dual var.}) \\
\text{s.t.} & x_1 + \frac{8}{3}x_2 \leq 4, & (y_1) \\
& x_1 + x_2 \leq 2 & (y_2) \\
& 2x_1 \leq 3 & (y_3) \\
& x_1, x_2 \geq 0.
\end{align}

min4y1+2y2+3y3(primal var.)s.t.y1+y2+2y3≥2,(x1)83y1+y2≥1,(x2)y1,y2,y3≥0.\begin{align}
\operatorname{min} & 4y_1 + 2y_2 + 3y_3 & (\text{primal var.}) \\
\text{s.t.} & y_1 + y_2 + 2y_3 \geq 2, & (x_1) \\
& \frac{8}{3}y_1 + y_2 \geq 1, & (x_2) \\
& y_1, y_2, y_3 \geq 0.
\end{align}







Dual can be viewed as the acquisition pricing problem: a buyer sets the prices for the three resources of the producer:

each of the constraints indicates that the prices are competitive or even better than producing each product by the producer itself,
the objective is to minimize the total acuisition cost.

section: Example 3 – Dual of the Transportation Problem
text:
Example 3 – Dual of the Transportation Problem



Recall that this is the problem, faced by the manufacturer, of selecting the pattern of product shipments between several fixed origins and desginations so as to minimize transportation cost while satisfying demand.






The primal is in standard form

minimize∑i,jcijxijsubject to∑j=1nxij=ai,i=1,2,…,m,∑i=1mxij=bj,j=1,2,…,n,xij≥0,i=1,2,…,m;j=1,2,…,n.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & \sum_{i,j} c_{ij}x_{ij} \\
\text{subject to} & \sum_{j=1}^n x_{ij} = a_i, \quad i = 1, 2, \ldots, m, \\
& \sum_{i=1}^m x_{ij} = b_j, \quad j = 1, 2, \ldots, n, \\
& x_{ij} \geq 0, \quad i = 1, 2, \ldots, m; \, j = 1, 2, \ldots, n.
\end{align}



The asymmetric version of the duality relation applies.

maximize∑i=1maiui+∑j=1nbjvjsubject toui+vj≤cij,i=1,2,…,m;j=1,2,…,n.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{maximize} & \sum_{i=1}^m a_iu_i + \sum_{j=1}^n b_jv_j \\
\text{subject to} & u_i + v_j \leq c_{ij}, \quad i = 1, 2, \ldots, m; \; j = 1,
2, \ldots, n.
\end{align}






Interpretation


Imagine that the company, responsible for shipping the product quantities from the origins to the destinations, plans to launch a new and simplified “pricing” scheme to the manufacturer:

charge $ui{\$}u_i for every unit shipped out from origin site ii; and $vj\$v_j for every unit shipped to the destination site jj.
The shipping company would select unit prices/costs u1,u2,…,umu_1, u_2, \ldots, u_m for the mm origins and v1,v2,…,vnv_1, v_2, \ldots, v_n for the nn destinations such that ui+vj≤ciju_i + v_j \leq c_{ij} for all i,ji, j.

This is to convince the manufacturer customer to accept the new scheme since ui+vju_i+ v_j represents the net amount the manufacturer must pay to ship a unit of product from origin ii to destination jj.

text:
Example 4 – Dual of the MDP Problem



Recall that the MDP problem is to find to find the optimal cost-to-go value yiy_i for state i=1,2,…,mi = 1, 2, \ldots, m such that





maximize∑i=1myisubject toyi−γ𝐩j⊤𝐲≤cj,∀j∈𝒜i,∀i=1,…,m.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{maximize} & \sum_{i=1}^m y_i & \\
\text{subject to} & y_i - \gamma \bm{p}_j^\top \bm{y} \leq c_j, & \forall j
\in \mathcal{A}_i, \\
& & \forall i = 1, \ldots, m.
\end{align}


The dual problem would be
minimize∑i=1m∑j∈𝒜jcjxjsubject to∑i=1m∑j∈𝒜i(𝐞i−γ𝐩j)xj=𝟏,xj≥0,∀j∈𝒜i,∀i=1,…,m,
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & \sum_{i=1}^m \sum_{j \in \mathcal{A}_j} c_j x_j \\
\text{subject to} & \sum_{i=1}^m \sum_{j \in \mathcal{A}_i} (\bm{e}_i - \gamma
\bm{p}_j)x_j = \bm{1}, \\
& x_j \geq 0, \;\; \forall j \in \mathcal{A}_i, \;\; \forall i = 1, \ldots, m,
\end{align}

where 𝐞i\bm{e}_i is the unit vector with 11 for the ithi^{\text{th}} entry and 00 everywhere else.







Variable xjx_j, j∈𝒜ij \in \mathcal{A}_i represents the expected total discounted present frequency, or the total expected present number of times taking action jj in a state ii, during the process.







Since cjc_j is the immediate cost of taking action jj once, cjxjc_jx_j represents the total expected present cost of taking action jj during the process so that the objective of the dual represents the overall expected present cost of the entire process.






When the objective of the dual is minimized, only one flux/frequency in each state would be positive, which establishes an optimal policy.

text:
Weak Duality
Throughout this section, we consider the primal-dual pair


minimize𝐜⊤𝐱subject to𝐀𝐱=𝐛,𝐱≥𝟎.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & \bm{c}^\top \bm{x} \\
\text{subject to} & \bm{Ax} = \bm{b}, \quad \bm{x} \geq \bm{0}.
\end{align}


maximize𝐲⊤𝐛subject to𝐲⊤𝐀≤𝐜⊤.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{maximize} & \bm{y}^\top \bm{b} \\
\text{subject to} & \bm{y}^\top \bm{A} \leq \bm{c}^\top.
\end{align}






Weak Duality Lemma


If 𝐱\bm{x} and 𝐲\bm{y} are feasible for the primal-dual pair, then 𝐜⊤𝐱≥𝐲⊤𝐛\bm{c}^\top\bm{x} \geq \bm{y}^\top\bm{b}.






Proof


We have 𝐲⊤𝐛=𝐲⊤𝐀𝐱≤𝐜⊤𝐱, \bm{y}^\top \bm{b} = \bm{y}^\top \bm{Ax} \leq \bm{c}^\top \bm{x},  the last inequality being valid sincd 𝐱≥𝟎\bm{x} \geq \bm{0} and 𝐲⊤𝐀≤𝐜⊤\bm{y}^\top \bm{A} \leq \bm{c}^\top.








Corollary


If 𝐱0\bm{x}_0 and 𝐲0\bm{y}_0 are feasible for the primal-dual pair and if 𝐜⊤𝐱0=𝐲0⊤𝐛\bm{c}^\top \bm{x}_0 = \bm{y}_0^\top \bm{b}, then 𝐱0\bm{x}_0 and 𝐲0\bm{y}_0 are optimal for their respective problems.

title: 02_duality
text:
Strong Duality



Duality Theorem of LP


If either of the primal-dual pair problems has a finite optimal solution, so does the other, and the corresponding values of the objective functions are equal. If either problem has an unbounded objective, the other problem has no feasible solution.






Proof


Firstly, the second statement is an immediate consequence of weak duality. If the primal is unbounded and 𝐲\bm{y} is feasible for the dual, we must have 𝐲⊤𝐛≤−M\bm{y}^\top \bm{b} \leq -M for arbitrarily large MM, which is clearly impossible.
Let us assume that the primal has a finite optimal solution and show that the dual has a solution with the same value (recall primal/dual are reversible). We prove that if the primal problem is feasible and its minimal value is bounded from below, then the system
𝐀𝐱=𝐛,𝐱≥𝟎,𝐀⊤𝐲≤𝐜,𝐜⊤𝐱−𝐛⊤𝐲≤0(1)
\begin{align}
\bm{Ax} = \bm{b}, &\quad \bm{x} \geq \bm{0}, \\
\bm{A}^\top \bm{y} &\leq \bm{c}, \\
\bm{c}^\top \bm{x} - &\bm{b}^\top \bm{y} \leq 0
\end{align}
 \qquad(1)
has a feasible solution pair 𝐱\bm{x} and 𝐲\bm{y}. The first system in Equation 1 is the primal constraint system, the second is the dual constraint system, and the third is the reversed duality gap, which, together with weak duality, implies zero-duality gap 𝐜⊤𝐱−𝐛⊤𝐲=0\bm{c}^\top \bm{x} - \bm{b}^\top \bm{y} = 0.

title: 02_duality
text:
Strong Duality



Proof - Continued -


We first show that the dual must be feasible, since otherwise, from Farkas’s lemma the algernative system to the second system Equation 1 must be feasible, that is, there is 𝐱′≥𝟎\bm{x}^\prime \geq \bm{0} such that (𝐀𝐱′=𝟎,𝐜⊤𝐱′=−1)(\bm{Ax^\prime} = \bm{0}, \; \bm{c}^\top\bm{x}^\prime = -1). Let 𝐱\bm{x} be any given feasible solution for the primal, then the solution 𝐱+α𝐱′\bm{x} + \alpha \bm{x}^\prime must also be feasible fro the primal for any scalar α>0\alpha > 0. But the primal objective value at this solution is 𝐜⊤(x+α𝐱′)=𝐜⊤𝐱+α𝐜⊤𝐱′=𝐜⊤𝐱−α
\bm{c}^\top(x + \alpha \bm{x}^\prime) = \bm{c}^\top \bm{x} + \alpha \bm{c}^\top
\bm{x}^\prime = \bm{c}^\top \bm{x} - \alpha
 which is unbounded from below as α→∞\alpha \rightarrow \infty leading to a contradiction.
Now, both the primal and the dual are feasible but suppose their optimal values are not equal; that is, the whole system Equation 1 remains infeasible. Then its alternative system must be feasible. That is, there are (𝐲′,𝐱′,τ)(\bm{y}^\prime, \bm{x}^\prime, \tau) to satisfy the constraints 𝐀𝐱′−𝐛τ=𝟎,𝐀⊤𝐲′−𝐜τ≤𝟎,𝐛⊤𝐲′−𝐜⊤𝐱′=1,𝐱′≥0,τ≥0.(2) \bm{Ax^\prime} - \bm{b}\tau = \bm{0}, \quad \bm{A}^\top \bm{y}^\prime -
\bm{c}\tau \leq \bm{0}, \quad \bm{b}^\top \bm{y}^\prime - \bm{c}^\top
\bm{x}^\prime = 1, \quad \bm{x}^\prime \geq 0, \quad \tau \geq 0.  \qquad(2)
Case 1: τ>0\tau > 0 in Equation 2, then we have 0≥(−𝐲′)⊤(𝐀𝐱′−𝐛τ)+(𝐱′)⊤(𝐀⊤𝐲′−𝐜τ)=τ(𝐛⊤𝐲′−𝐜⊤𝐱′)=τ 0 \geq (-\bm{y}^\prime)^\top (\bm{Ax^\prime} - \bm{b}\tau) +
(\bm{x}^\prime)^\top (\bm{A}^\top \bm{y}^\prime - \bm{c}\tau) =
\tau(\bm{b}^\top\bm{y}^\prime - \bm{c}^\top \bm{x}^\prime) = \tau  which is a contradiction.
Case 2: τ=0\tau = 0 in Equation 2, then we let 𝐱\bm{x} be any feasible solution for the primal and 𝐲\bm{y} be any feasible solution for the dual. Again 𝐱+α𝐱′\bm{x} + \alpha \bm{x}^\prime must also be feasible for the primal and 𝐲+α𝐲′\bm{y} + \alpha \bm{y}^\prime must also be feasible for the dual, and the objective gap at this pair is 𝐜⊤(𝐱+α𝐱′)−𝐛⊤(𝐲+α𝐲′)=𝐜⊤𝐱−𝐛⊤𝐲+α(𝐜⊤𝐱′−𝐛⊤𝐲′)=𝐜⊤𝐱−𝐛⊤𝐲−α \bm{c}^\top(\bm{x} + \alpha \bm{x}^\prime) - \bm{b}^\top(\bm{y} + \alpha
\bm{y}^\prime) = \bm{c}^\top \bm{x} - \bm{b}^\top \bm{y} + \alpha(\bm{c}^\top
\bm{x}^\prime - \bm{b}^\top \bm{y}^\prime) = \bm{c}^\top \bm{x} - \bm{b}^\top
\bm{y} - \alpha  which is not bounded below by 00 as α→∞\alpha \rightarrow \infty and creates a contradition to weak duality.

title: 02_duality
text:
Primal-Dual Optimal Solutions



Suppose that for the LP in the standard primal form minimize𝐜⊤𝐱subject to𝐀𝐱=𝐛,𝐱≥𝟎,(3)
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & \bm{c}^\top \bm{x} \\
\text{subject to} & \bm{Ax} = \bm{b}, \quad \bm{x} \geq \bm{0},
\end{align}
 \qquad(3) we have the optimal basic feasible solution 𝐱=(𝐱B,𝟎)\bm{x} = (\bm{x}_B, \bm{0}) with the corresponding basis 𝐁\bm{B}.

 

Partition 𝐀=[𝐁𝐃]\bm{A} = \begin{bmatrix} \bm{B} & \bm{D} \end{bmatrix}, where the primal basic feasible solution 𝐱𝐁=𝐁−1𝐛\bm{x}_{\bm{B}} = \bm{B}^{-1}\bm{b} is optimal.



We shall determine a solution of the dual program

maximize𝐲⊤𝐛subject to𝐲⊤𝐀≤𝐜⊤,(4)
\begin{align}
\operatorname{maximize} & \bm{y}^\top \bm{b} \\
\text{subject to} & \bm{y}^\top\bm{A} \leq \bm{c}^\top,
\end{align}
 \qquad(4) in terms of 𝐁\bm{B}.

Define 𝐲⊤=𝐜𝐁⊤𝐁−1\bm{y}^\top = \bm{c}_{\bm{B}}^\top \bm{B}^{-1}, which i s adual basic solution (The components of 𝐜𝐁\bm{c}_{\bm{B}} are those of 𝐜\bm{c} assoc. w/ the columns of the submatrix 𝐁\bm{B} according to the same index order.).




If, in addition, 𝐲⊤𝐀≤𝐜⊤\bm{y}^\top\bm{A} \leq \bm{c}^\top, then 𝐲\bm{y} is feasible and a basic feasible solution for the dual — an extreme point of the dual feasible region. On the other hand

𝐲⊤𝐛=𝐜𝐁⊤𝐁−1𝐛=𝐜𝐁⊤𝐱𝐁,
\bm{y}^\top\bm{b} = \bm{c}_{\bm{B}}^\top \bm{B}^{-1}\bm{b} =
\bm{c}_{\bm{B}}^\top\bm{x}_{\bm{B}},

and thus the value of the dual objective function for the 𝐲\bm{y} is equal to the value of the primal problem. Hence 𝐲\bm{y} is optimal for the dual!

title: 02_duality
text:
Primal-Dual Optimal Solution – Example



Theorem


Let the linear program Equation 3 have an optimal basic feasible solution corresponding to the basis 𝐁\bm{B}. Then the vector 𝐲\bm{y} satisfying 𝐲⊤=𝐜𝐁⊤𝐁−1\bm{y}^\top = \bm{c}_{\bm{B}}^\top \bm{B}^{-1} is an optimal soluion to the dual program Equation 4 if it is dual feasible. The optimal values of both problems are equal.







Primal

minimize18x1+12x2+2x3+6x4subject to3x1+x2−2x3+x4=2x1+3x2−x4=2x1,x2,x3,x4≥0.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & 18x_1 + 12x_2 + 2x_3 + 6x_4 \\
\text{subject to} & 3x_1 + x_2 - 2x_3 + x_4 = 2 \\
& x_1 + 3x_2 - x_4 = 2 \\
& x_1, x_2, x_3, x_4 \geq 0.
\end{align}





Columns of 𝐀\bm{A} and 𝐛\bm{b} are represented in the requirement space.
A basic solution represents construction of 𝐛\bm{b} with positive weights, xjx_j’s, on two of the 𝐚j\bm{a}_j’s.
Primal problem: find weights for the conic combination of 𝐛\bm{b} by these columns such that the weighted sum (by cjc_j’s) of the weights is minimized.













Dual

maximize2λ1+2λ2subject to3λ1+λ2≤18,λ1+3λ2≤12−2λ1≤2,λ1−λ2≤6.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{maximize} & 2\lambda_1 + 2\lambda_2 & \\
\text{subject to} & 3\lambda_1 + \lambda_2 \leq 18, & \lambda_1 + 3\lambda_2 \leq 12 \\
& -2\lambda_1 \leq 2, & \lambda_1 - \lambda_2 \leq 6.
\end{align}





Each column 𝐚j\bm{a}_j of the primal defines a constraint of the dual as a half-space whose boundary is ⊥\perp to that column vector and is located at a point determined by cjc_j.
Dual obj. is maximized at an extreme point of the dual feasible region.

At this point exactly two dual constraints are active.
These active constraints also correspond to an optimal basis of the primal.

The vector defining the dual objective is a conic combination of the active constraint vectors: 𝐛=x1𝐚1+x2𝐚2\bm{b} = x_1\bm{a}_1 + x_2\bm{a}_2, with xix_i’s being the optimal solution of the primal!

title: 02_duality
text:
Dual Multipliers — Shadow Prices

𝐲⊤=𝐜𝐁⊤𝐁−1\bm{y}^\top = \bm{c}_{\bm{B}}^\top \bm{B}^{-1} is not a solution to the dual unless 𝐁\bm{B} is an optimal basis for the primal.

The vector 𝐲\bm{y} may be used at every step to calculate the relative cost coefficients or reduced gradients (to be introduced later).
𝐲⊤=𝐜𝐁⊤𝐁−1\bm{y}^\top = \bm{c}_{\bm{B}}^\top \bm{B}^{-1} is called the vector of simplex multipliers or shadow prices.

The components of the 𝐚j\bm{a}_j’s and 𝐛\bm{b} tells us how to construct these vectors from the 𝐞i\bm{e}_i’s.
Given any basis 𝐁\bm{B}, any other vector can be constructed (synthetically) as a linear combination of these basis vectors.

If there is a unit cost cjc_j associated with each basis vector 𝐚j\bm{a}_j, then the cost of a (synthetic) vector constructed from the basis can be calculated as the corresponding linear combination of the cjc_j’s associated with the basis.
In particular, the cost of 𝐞i\bm{e}_i, when constructed from the basis 𝐁\bm{B}, is yiy_i.
Thus the yiy_i’s can be interpreted as synthetic prices of the unit vectors.

title: 02_duality
text:
Dual Multipliers — Shadow Prices

Any vector can be expressed in terms of the basis 𝐁\bm{B} in two steps:

express the unit vector 𝐞i\bm{e}_i in terms of the basis,
express the desired vector as a linear combination of the 𝐞i\bm{e}_i’s.

The corresponding synthetic cost of a vector constructed from the basis 𝐁\bm{B} can be correspondingly computed directly by:

find the synthetic price of the 𝐚i\bm{a}_i’s.
use these prices to evaluate the cost of the linear combination of 𝐞i\bm{e}_i’s.

Thus, the simplex multipliers can be used to quickly evaluate the synthetic cost of any vector that is expressed in terms of the unit vectors 𝐞i\bm{e}_i’s.
The difference between the true cost of this vector and the synthetic cost is the relative cost.

The process of calculating the syntheic cost of a vector w.r.t. a given basis by using the simplex multipliers is sometimes referred to as pricing out the vector.





Optimality of the primal corresponds to the situation where every vector 𝐚1,𝐚2,…,𝐚n\bm{a}_1, \bm{a}_2, \ldots, \bm{a}_n is cheaper when constructed from the basis than when purchased directly at its own price. Thus, we have
𝐲⊤𝐚j≤cj for j=1,2,…,nor𝐲⊤𝐀≤𝐜⊤. \bm{y}^\top \bm{a}_j \leq c_j \;\; \text{ for }  j = 1, 2 , \ldots, n \quad
\text{or} \quad \bm{y}^\top \bm{A} \leq \bm{c}^\top.

title: 02_duality
text:
Sensitivity


z(𝐛):=minimize𝐜⊤𝐱subject to𝐀𝐱=𝐛,𝐱≥𝟎.(5)
\begin{align}
z(\bm{b}) := & \operatorname{minimize} &\bm{c}^\top \bm{x} & \\
& \text{subject to} &\bm{Ax} = \bm{b}, & \bm{x} \geq \bm{0}.
\end{align} 
 \qquad(5)

Let the optimal basis be 𝐁\bm{B} with the corresponding solution 𝐱=(𝐱𝐁,𝟎)\bm{x} = (\bm{x}_{\bm{B}}, \bm{0}), where 𝐱𝐁=𝐁−1𝐛\bm{x}_{\bm{B}} = \bm{B}^{-1}\bm{b}.
A solution to the corresponding dual is 𝐲⊤=𝐜𝐁⊤𝐁−1\bm{y}^\top = \bm{c}_{\bm{B}}^\top \bm{B}^{-1}.



Let’s make a small change in the vector 𝐛\bm{b}, which will not change the optimal basis. Thus for 𝐛+Δ𝐛\bm{b} + \Delta\bm{b}, the optimal solution is 𝐱=(𝐱+Δ𝐱𝐁,𝟎), \bm{x} = (\bm{x} + \Delta\bm{x}_{\bm{B}}, \bm{0}),  where Δ𝐱𝐁=𝐁−1Δ𝐛\Delta\bm{x}_{\bm{B}} = \bm{B}^{-1}\Delta\bm{b}.
Thus the corresponding increment in the cost function is

z(𝐛+Δ𝐛)−z(𝐛)=𝐜𝐁⊤Δ𝐱𝐁=𝐲⊤Δ𝐛.(6) z(\bm{b} + \Delta\bm{b}) - z(\bm{b}) = \bm{c}_{\bm{B}}^\top
\Delta\bm{x}_{\bm{B}} = \bm{y}^\top\Delta\bm{b}.  \qquad(6)





Sensitivity of the optimal cost


𝐲\bm{y} gives the sensitivity of the optimal cost wih respect to changes in the vector 𝐛\bm{b}. If a new program were solved with 𝐛\bm{b} changed to 𝐛+Δ𝐛\bm{b} + \Delta\bm{b}, the change in the optimal value of the objective function would be 𝐲⊤Δ𝐛\bm{y}^\top \Delta\bm{b}.




This interpretation of the dual vector 𝐲\bm{y} is intimately related to its interpretation as a vector of simplex multipliers.

Since yiy_i is the price of the unit vector 𝐞i\bm{e}_i when constructed from the basis 𝐁\bm{B}, it directly measures the change in cost due to a change in the ithi^{\text{th}} component of the rhs vector 𝐛\bm{b}.

title: 02_duality
text:
Sensitivity – Examples

Diet Problem



yiy_i is the maximum price per unit that the dietitian would be willing to pay for a small amount of the ithi^{\text{th}} nutrient.
Decreasing the amount of the nutrient that must be supplied by food will reduce the food bill by yiy_i dollars per unit.







Production Problem



Manufacturer must select levels x1,x2,…,xnx_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n of nn production activites in order to meet certain required levels of output b1,b2,…,bmb_1, b_2, \ldots, b_m while minimizing production costs.
yiy_i’s are the marginal prices of the outputs.
They show directly how much the production cost varies if a small change is made in the output levels.

The minimal value function z(𝐛)z(\bm{b}) of the linear program Equation 5 is a convex function, and the optimal dual solution 𝐲*\bm{y}^\ast is a subgradient vector of the function at 𝐛\bm{b}, written as ∇z(𝐛)=𝐲*\nabla z(\bm{b}) = \bm{y}^\ast.






Proof


Let 𝐱1\bm{x}^1 and 𝐱2\bm{x}^2 be two optimal solutions of Equation 5 corresponding to two right-hand-side vectors 𝐛1\bm{b}^1 and 𝐛2\bm{b}^2, resp. Then, for any scalar 0≤α≤10 \leq \alpha \leq 1, α𝐱1+(1−α)𝐱2\alpha \bm{x}^1 + (1-\alpha)\bm{x}^2 is a feasible solution of Equation 5 with 𝐛=α𝐛1+(1−α)𝐛2\bm{b} = \alpha \bm{b}^1 + (1-\alpha)\bm{b}^2 so that the minimal value is

z(\alpha \bm{b}^1 + (1-\alpha)\bm{b}^2) \leq \bm{c}^\top (\alpha \bm{x}^1 +
(1-\alpha)\bm{x}^2) = \alpha \bm{c}^\top \bm{x}^1 + (1-\alpha)\bm{c}^\top
\bm{x}^2 = \alpha z(\bm{b}^1) + (1-\alpha)z(\bm{b}^2)

which implies the first claim.
Furthermore, let 𝐲1\bm{y}^1 be the optimal dual solution with 𝐛=𝐛1\bm{b} = \bm{b}^1. Note that 𝐲1\bm{y}^1 remains feasible for the dual of primal with 𝐛=𝐛2\bm{b} = \bm{b}^2 because the dual feasible region is independent of changes in 𝐛\bm{b}. Thus
z(𝐛2)−z(𝐛1)=𝐜⊤𝐱2−(𝐲1)(zero-duality gap theorem)≥(𝐲1)⊤𝐛2−(𝐲1)⊤𝐛1(weak
duality)=(𝐲1)⊤(𝐛2−𝐛1),
\begin{align}
z(\bm{b}^2) - z(\bm{b}^1) &= \bm{c}^\top \bm{x}^2 - (\bm{y}^1) &
\text{(zero-duality gap theorem)} \\
&\geq (\bm{y}^1)^\top \bm{b}^2 - (\bm{y}^1)^\top \bm{b}^1 & \text{(weak
duality)} \\
&= (\bm{y}^1)^\top (\bm{b}^2 - \bm{b}^1),
\end{align}

which proves the second claim.

Complementary Slackness





Theorem (Complementary slackness — asymmetric form).


Let 𝐱\bm{x} and 𝐲\bm{y} be feasible solutions for the primal and dual programs, respectively, in the pair



minimize𝐜⊤𝐱subject to𝐀𝐱=𝐛,𝐱≥𝟎.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & \bm{c}^\top \bm{x} \\
\text{subject to} & \bm{Ax} = \bm{b}, \quad \bm{x} \geq \bm{0}.
\end{align}



minimize𝐲⊤𝐛subject to𝐲⊤𝐀≤𝐜⊤.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & \bm{y}^\top \bm{b} \\
\text{subject to} & \bm{y}^\top \bm{A} \leq \bm{c}^\top.
\end{align}




A necessary and sufficient condition that they both be optimal solutions is that for all jj


xj>0⇒𝐲⊤𝐚j=cjx_j > 0 \; \Rightarrow \; \bm{y}^\top \bm{a}_j = c_j,
xj=0⇐𝐲⊤𝐚j<cjx_j = 0 \; \Leftarrow \; \bm{y}^\top \bm{a}_j < c_j.









Proof (of Complementary Slackness)


If the stated conditions hold, then clearly (𝐲⊤𝐀−𝐜⊤)𝐱=0(\bm{y}^\top \bm{A} - \bm{c}^\top)\bm{x} = 0. Thus 𝐲⊤𝐛=𝐜⊤𝐱\bm{y}^\top\bm{b} = \bm{c}^\top\bm{x}, and by strong duality, the two solutions are optimal.
Conversely, if the two solutions are optimal, it must hold, by strong duality, that 𝐲⊤𝐛=𝐜⊤𝐱\bm{y}^\top \bm{b} = \bm{c}^\top \bm{x} and hence that (𝐲⊤𝐀−𝐜⊤)𝐱=0(\bm{y}^\top \bm{A} - \bm{c}^\top)\bm{x} = 0. Since each component of 𝐱\bm{x} is nonnegative and each component of 𝐲⊤𝐀−𝐜⊤\bm{y}^\top\bm{A} - \bm{c}^\top is nonpositive, the conditions 1.1. and 22. must hold.








Theorem (Strict complementary slackness — asymmetric form)


Let both the primal and dual problems be feasible. Then there is an optimal solution pair 𝐱\bm{x} and 𝐲\bm{y} such that for all jj


xj>0⇔𝐲⊤𝐚j=cjx_j > 0 \; \Leftrightarrow \; \bm{y}^\top \bm{a}_j = c_j,
xj=0⇔𝐲⊤𝐚j<cjx_j = 0 \; \Leftrightarrow \; \bm{y}^\top \bm{a}_j < c_j.

Economic interpretation



Let us think in terms of the diet problem, which is the primal part of a symmetric pair of dual problems.
Suppose that the optimal diet supplies more than bjb_j units of the jthj^{\text{th}} nutrient.

This means that the dietitian would be unwilling to pay anything for small quantities of that nutrient since the availability of it would not reduce the cost of the optimal diet.

This, in view of our previous interpretation of yjy_j as a marginal price, implies yj=0y_j = 0 which is 4.4. of the Corollary.
